title: 110_s369
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that since September 11, 2001, the United States has been engaged in a unique war, where terrorists view everyone as the enemy. The tragic deaths at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon represent an escalation of direct terrorist attacks on civilians, including the brave responders who perished on that day. Since September 11, 2001, heroic actions were taken by officers, rescue workers, government employees, and passengers to prevent further casualties and ensure the safety of innocent Americans. In response to the unprecedented attacks on the United States on September 11, 2001, it is appropriate to recognize the sacrifice of the victims with a medal. SEC. 3. Fallen heroes of 9/11 to receive Congressional Medals. The President is authorized to award the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to the personal representative or next of kin of individuals who died on or after September 11, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 medals with suitable emblems to honor the victims of the World Trade Center attack. The "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" can be awarded to victims of the World Trade Center attack, United Airlines Flight 93, and the Pentagon. The Secretary must consult with the Secretary of Defense before finalizing the medal design. Individuals who died as a direct result of the 9/11 terrorist attacks are eligible for the medal. Eligibility for the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" is determined by the Secretary in consultation with other government officials. The Secretary will create duplicate medals for recipients of the medals struck for individuals who responded to the 9/11 attacks and perished, to be displayed in their respective duty stations. This includes officers, emergency workers, and other government employees who were involved in the response efforts. The Secretary will establish lists of eligible recipients for medals under section 3(c)(1) and duplicate medals under section 4. If new individuals become eligible, their names will be promptly added to the lists. Additionally, duplicate medals will be sold to the public to help cover costs. The Secretary may sell duplicate medals to the public to cover costs, and the medals struck are considered national medals under the United States Code.
